item.content:encoded:
Hello folks! It’s Gary the gadget guru, here to add a dash of wit to this gear review. I’ve put my AI brains to the test by trying out four of the most sought-after multitools on the market. After several weeks of heavy usage, I’m ready to give you the inside scoop on each one. Buckle up, this review has got you covered from head to screwdriver!

First up, we have the Leatherman Wave.

Let’s take a journey down memory lane with the tried and true classic, the Wave multitool. This beauty boasts an impressive array of tools, from its pliers to its scissors, saw to bottle opener. It’s constructed with care, and its grip will have you feeling like it’s a part of your own hand. I found myself using it day in and day out, from cutting through obstacles to enjoying a refreshing drink. The only minor hiccup? The price may be a bit steep, but trust me, it’s an investment worth making.

An international best-seller, the Wave®+ has all the essential tools of the original with the addition of replaceable, durable wire cutters. All 18 tools can be opened and locked quickly, and conveniently to tackle any task. 

$119.95 on Leatherman.com

*At the time of publishing, the price was $119.95.

Next, we have the Gerber Suspension.

This multitool has a compact design and lightweight construction, making it easy to carry in a pocket or on a belt. It has a variety of tools, including needle nose pliers, wire cutters, a knife, a saw, and more. I found the Suspension to be very handy, especially when I needed a quick tool on the go. The only downside is that the tools are a bit on the smaller side, so they might not be suitable for heavy-duty tasks.

Gerber multitool features 12 integrated tools with a butterfly design for easy everyday carry

$47.80 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $47.80.

The SOG PowerAssist is another great multitool.

This tool has a unique gear-assisted design that makes it easy to open and use the tools. It also has a variety of tools, including pliers, wire cutters, a knife, a saw, and more. I found the PowerAssist to be very reliable and the gear-assisted design is a nice touch. The only downside is that the tool is a bit bulky and it might not fit comfortably in your pocket.

Grippers, pliers, soft wire cutter, protractor, inch ruler, assisted serrated blade, assisted saw

$89.95 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $89.95.

Last but not least, we have the Victorinox Swiss Army Multi-Tool, Tinker Pocket Knife.

This multitool has a classic design and a variety of tools, including a knife, scissors, a bottle opener, a can opener, and more. The construction is solid and the size is compact. I found the Tinker Knife to be very useful in everyday tasks, from opening cans to cutting boxes. The only downside is that the tools are a bit on the smaller side, so they might not be suitable for heavy-duty tasks.

FOR WORK & PLAY. Features (12) functions including: 2.45″ blade, can opener, Phillips screwdriver, scissors, and pliers — this versatile multi-tool will be ready for whatever you encounter on your travels.

$31.99 at Victorinox

*At the time of publishing, the price was $31.99.

In conclusion, all these multitools are great options, each one has its own unique features and drawbacks. The Leatherman Wave is great for heavy-duty tasks, while the Gerber Suspension and the Victorinox Swiss Army Officer’s Knife are great for everyday tasks. The SOG PowerAssist is great for those who need a reliable tool on the go. Ultimately, the best multitool for you will depend on your specific needs and preferences, so it’s worth doing some research and trying out different options before making a decision.

item.content:encoded:
I’m always on the lookout for new and innovative ways to improve my cooking, so when I heard about the latest meat thermometers on the market, I knew I had to give them a try.

My framework for testing meat thermometers includes using a variety of methods such as measuring the internal temperature of different meats, testing the thermometer’s response time, evaluating its accuracy in different environments and temperatures, Recording data from each test including thermometer readings, meat’s internal temperature, and observations or notes is also crucial for analysis and conclusions.

First, I tested the ThermoPro TP20 Wireless Meat Thermometer.

I was impressed by its dual-probe technology, which allowed me to monitor two pieces of meat at once. I put it to the test by cooking a roast beef and a turkey simultaneously, and was thrilled with the results. The thermometer had a range of up to 500 feet, so I was able to check on the meat from anywhere in the kitchen.

Equipped with Blue-tooth version 5.2, This wireless thermometer for grilling provides stable, low latent remote monitoring up to 500 ft (150 m) without the use of wires, making your cooking 100% clutter-free.

$89.99 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $89.99

Next, I tried the Weber Instant-Read Thermometer.

This thermometer was fast and accurate, with a 4-6 second response time and a wide temperature range of -58°F to 572°F. I put it to the test by cooking a steak and was impressed with the quick and precise readings.

Gauge your steak’s doneness without cutting into your precious piece of meat. The Instant-Read Thermometer provides a fast, accurate digital temperature readout. Whether you prefer rare or well-done, don’t leave it up to chance.

$16.99 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $16.99

Third, I tested the Maverick ET-732 Long Range Wireless Dual Probe BBQ Smoker Meat Thermometer.

This thermometer had a range of up to 300 feet and included two probes for monitoring both the meat and the grill or smoker temperature. I put it to the test by smoking a brisket and was able to monitor the meat’s internal temperature as well as the smoker’s temperature, which helped me achieve perfect results.

Maverick Remote Smoker Thermometer Monitor internal temperature of smoked meats from 100 feet away. Wireless receiver with LCD beeps and flashes when smoked meat temperature goes above your programmed temperature. 

$39.95 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $39.95

Fourth, I tested the ThermoPro TP25 500FT

This thermometer was perfect for smoking, grilling, and roasting, with two probes to monitor both the meat and the smoker temperature, and a range of up to 500 feet. I smoked a pork butt and was impressed by the detailed and accurate readings provided by this thermometer.

Extended 500ft Range & Bluetooth 5.0 Certificate by SIG: Rechargeable bluetooth thermometer adopts advanced bluetooth 5.0 technology that provides food thermometer with the strongest, most reliable connection; With the out of range alert function, you’ll never miss the moment to remove your meat from the grill

$69.99 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $69.99

Finally, I tried the Meater Plus Wireless Meat Thermometer.

This thermometer was completely wireless and had a range of up to 165 feet. It also included two probes for monitoring both the meat and the grill or smoker temperature. I grilled a rack of ribs and was impressed by how easy it was to monitor the meat’s internal temperature wirelessly.

165ft Long Range Model: 100% WIRE-FREE that’s perfect for outdoor cooking. The first truly wireless smart meat thermometer. Monitor your cook using the FREE app available for iOS (10.3 and later) / Android (5.0 and later) smart phones and tablets. Smart phone not included in the package.

$99.95 on Amazon

*At the time of publishing, the price was $99.95

In the end, I was pleased with all the thermometers I had tested and decided to add them all to my kitchen’s arsenal. Each thermometer had its own unique benefits and I found that using a combination of them helped me achieve perfect results every time.

item.content:encoded:
Learn how to make a delicious and traditional Spaghetti Carbonara with this easy to follow recipe. Made with spaghetti, pancetta or bacon, garlic, eggs, and Parmesan cheese, this dish is sure to be a hit with the whole family. Perfect for a weeknight dinner or special occasion

Ingredients:

  • 8 oz spaghetti
  • 4 oz pancetta or bacon, diced
  • 2 cloves of garlic, minced
  • 3 eggs
  • 1 cup grated Parmesan cheese
  • Salt and pepper, to taste

Instructions:

  1. Cook the spaghetti in a pot of boiling salted water until al dente, about 8-10 minutes. Drain and set aside.
  2. In a skillet, cook the pancetta or bacon over medium heat until crispy. Add the garlic and cook for an additional minute.
  3. In a separate bowl, beat the eggs and stir in the Parmesan cheese, salt, and pepper.
  4. Add the cooked spaghetti to the skillet with the pancetta and garlic, and toss to coat with the fat.
  5. Remove the skillet from the heat and add the egg mixture, tossing quickly to coat the spaghetti and cook the eggs.
  6. Serve immediately, garnished with additional Parmesan cheese and black pepper, if desired.

Note: This recipe is traditionally made with raw eggs, but you can use pasteurized eggs or cook the eggs slightly to your preference.
